awd_titl_txt: Tidal dissipation in compact white dwarf binaries and exoplanetary systems
awd_abstract_narration: This project will support a postdoctoral scholar and graduate student?s efforts to develop code dealing with tidal dissipation in binary systems, with a focus on exoplanetary systems containing hot Jupiters.  The investigators plan to do ab initio calculations of the tidal dissipation rate as a function of orbital period, mass and spin.  Results of this work will be applicable to astrophysics, planetary science and fluid dynamics.  In addition to publishing in refereed journals, the PI will make numerical results publicly available, and train a grad student and postdoctoral researcher, and carry out ?Math/Science Days? at a local middle school.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In the last few years, the PI, with graduate students, have carried

out a series of theoretical studies on dynamical tides in compact

white dwarf (WD) binaries and exoplanetary systems containing hot

Jupiters.  Although the properties of these two types of systems and

the related applications are quite different, they can be studied with

similar theoretical and numerical tools. The accomplished research

consists of two parts:

(1) We have systematically studied dynamical tidal excitation and

dissipation of low-frequency internal waves in compact WD binaries

using realistic WD models. We have calculated ab initio

the tidal dissipation rate as a function of the orbital period, the WD

mass and spin, and therefore determined the spin-orbit synchronization

rate and the tidal luminosity prior to binary merger. The results of

this research are useful for understanding the observability of

pre-merger WDs and the outcome of final mergers.

(2) We have studied dynamical tides in various types of host stars of

hot Jupiters on an inclined orbit to understand how tidal dissipation

may affect the spin-orbit misalignment angle and orbital decay. We have

also study dynamical tides (including thermal tides) in hot

Jupiters and explore how they may contribute to the observed planetary

radius ``anomaly''.

 

Broader impacts: Our research is multidisciplinary in nature,

involving astrophysics, planetary sciences and fluid dynamics, and

thus is of interest to a broad scientific community.  We have

published our research results in refereed journals and presented in

appropriate scientific meetings. We have also incoporated our results

into classroom teaching as well as lectures to the general public and

high school students. The main funding for this proposal has been used

to provide GRA support for several graduate students, who have

received training in many of the multidisciplinary areas, as well as

in scientific computing. We have also engaged several undergraduate

students in our research.
